{{About|the New Zealand economist|the Scottish footballer|Brian Easton (footballer)}}

'''Brian Easton''' (born 1943) is an [[economist]] from [[New Zealand]]. He has been economics columnist for the [[New Zealand Listener]] magazine for more than 34 years, giving him a high public profile nationally. He has held a number of university teaching posts and also works as an independent commentator.<ref name="website">[http://www.eastonbh.ac.nz Brian Easton<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Easton is known for his criticism of economic orthodoxy.

==Background==
Easton was born in 1943 and grew up in Christchurch, New Zealand. He holds degrees in mathematics and economics from the [[University of Canterbury]], and in economics from [[Victoria University of Wellington]]. 

==Career==
Easton was director of the [[New Zealand Institute of Economic Research]] from 1981 to 1986.<ref name=DF_NZAE>{{cite web |url= http://www.nzae.org.nz/nzae-news/distinguished-fellow/brian-easton-awarded-distinguished-fellow-of-nzae/ |title=Brian Easton awarded Distinguished Fellow of NZAE |date=1 July 2005 |publisher=New Zealand Association of Economists |accessdate=16 December 2012}}</ref> He is a Fellow of the [[Royal Statistical Society]], a Chartered Statistician, and a Member of the [[Royal Society of New Zealand]].

==Publication==
As author, co-author or editor of more than 30 books, Easton writes regularly for the NZ Listener<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.listener.co.nz/search.do?q=Brian+Easton |title=New Zealand Listener |publisher=Listener.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2010-03-02}}</ref> and other journals and newspapers. His recent books include ''Globalisation and the Wealth of Nations'' ([[Auckland University Press]], 2007), ''The Commercialisation of New Zealand'' (AUP, 1997), ''In Stormy Seas: The Post-War New Zealand Economy'' (UOP, 1997), ''The Whimpering of the State: Policy after MMP'' (AUP, 1999)<ref>[http://www.auckland.ac.nz/uoa/aup/book/the-whimpering-of-the-state.cfm The Whimpering of the State — Auckland University Press]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref> and ''The Nationbuilders'' (AUP, 2001). He was included in ''Speaking Truth to Power: Public Intellectuals Rethink New Zealand'',<ref>[http://www.auckland.ac.nz/uoa/aup/book/2007/speaking-truth-to-power.cfm Speaking Truth to Power — Auckland University Press]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref> edited by Laurence Simmons (AUP, 2007).

==Academia==
Easton has held a number of scholarships and fellowships including visiting fellowships at the University of Melbourne, as Richard Downing Research Professor, Georgetown and Harvard Universities, as a Fulbright NZ Distinguished Visiting Fellow<ref>[http://www.otago.ac.nz/news/news/2004/16b-02-04_press_release.html 2004 Media Release, University of Otago, New Zealand]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref> and a Marsden Fellowship<ref>[http://www.rsnz.org/funding/marsden_fund/awards_2003.php RSNZ/Marsden Fund/2003 results]{{Dead link|date=March 2010}}</ref> (2003–2006). In 2002 he was appointed to the New Zealand Prime Ministerâ€™s Growth and Innovation Advisory Board<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.giab.govt.nz/members/index.html |title=Members | Growth and Innovation Advisory Board |publisher=Giab.govt.nz |date= |accessdate=2010-03-02}}</ref> and, in 2005, he was made a Distinguished Fellow of the New Zealand Association of Economists.<ref name=DF_NZAE/> He has documented his current work activity and interests in his personal web site.<ref name="website"/>
